Do Not Compare Integers and Floats in C++: Sorting Pitfalls, UB & Type Conversion Explained - Egor Suvorov - ACCU 2025 Short Talks
---

C++ developers often rely on simple comparisons like `a ＜ b`, but when mixing integers and floats—especially `long long` and `double`—such comparisons can lead to serious problems. In this lightning talk from ACCU Conference 2025, Egor Suvorov exposes the hidden dangers of comparing float and int types in C++ and how these comparisons can trigger undefined behavior in standard algorithms like `std::sort`.

When sorting heterogeneous data, implicit type conversion from `long long` to `double` can lead to rounding errors, comparator contradictions, and ultimately cause your program to crash, freeze, or return incorrect results. This talk demonstrates exactly how C++ float rounding, numeric limits, and NaN values can introduce subtle, hard-to-detect bugs—especially when comparing floats and ints directly
title: C++ Sorting Pitfalls, UB & Type Conversion Explained
